text: South Korea has one of the most
interesting and erratic cultures in the
world you can't go anywhere without
something making you scratch your head
and wonder
[Applause]
after spending two years of my life
living and traveling through this
country I've gotten to know Korean
culture pretty well and while it's a
very open and capitalistic society where
most things are accepted Koreans are
very superstitious people and you must
be respectful of this before coming the
following are eight things you just
cannot do in South Korea one stick
chopsticks in your rice bowl
this action signifies death because it's
funerals Koreans burn incense upright in
a bowl of sand if you stick your
chopsticks vertically in a rice bowl you
will get horrible looks so consider
yourself warned
to throw toilet paper in the toilet the
plumbing systems in Korea are not made
to flush toilet paper so you must put it
in the bin yes even after doing your
business trust me you don't want to be
that guy who overflows the toilet
3 write someone's name with a red pen to
avoid getting scolded at make sure to
always write in black or blue pen
writing in red ink which is like blood
somehow means that a person will die
soon or that you want them to die for
wear shoes indoors this strictly applies
to houses and may also apply to schools
cafes and restaurants Koreans are very
clean people and they always remove
their outdoor shoes when going indoors
most homes will have a little area to
keep your shoes so just do it 5 talk
loudly on the metro Koreans hardly speak
on the subway and when they do it's only
a small whisper it's almost eerie to
witness thousands of people crammed into
a small space completely without sound
but they respect one another
and you must do the same 6 assume people
speak English excuse me do you know
where the airport is how do you know
okay hello hi do you know how to get to
the airport the vast majority of Koreans
can speak or understand English at a
basic level while it's getting more
common for the younger generation to
know the language it still cannot be
assumed so learn a few Korean words like
annyeonghaseyo and comes to hamnida 7
use one hand to give or receive as
you've probably realized by now Korean
culture revolves around respect
and one of the best ways to show high
regard is by using two hands whenever
you give or receive something
this goes for pouring soju shots passing
a phone or even opening a door eight
refused to bow to the elderly instead of
shaking hands hugging or kissing Koreans
greet each other by bowing it's a common
way to say hello thank you and goodbye
and the older the person is the deeper
bow you have to give all right we are in
a taxi now we are heading out of Seoul
it's always a fun and unique experience
here in Korea but respecting the culture
is a must
while none of the things mentioned above
are illegal and you can probably get
away with doing them as a tourist I
highly recommend keeping them in your
back pocket so you don't offend anyone
in this lovely country called South
Korea
[Music]
I'm Dubinski and if you like my travel
videos please click Subscribe and join
me as I plan to visit every country in
the world
